inlineContent.text: This project provides a cluster runtime implementation for the distributed actors language feature.
This library is currently released as
preview software. While we anticipate very few changes, please be mindful that until a stable 1.0 version is announced, this library does not guarantee source compatibility.
This project will continue to be polished alongside the beta releases of Xcode and Swift 5.7, with the intention to release a source-stable 1.0 release around the time a stable Swift 5.7 is released.
Please note that this project requires the latest
language features, and as such to work with it (and the
feature in general), you must be using the latest Xcode beta releases, or a nightly 5.7 development toolchain Swift which you can download from

abstract.text: A peer-to-peer cluster actor system implementation for Swift.
Useful error wrapper which performs an best effort Error serialization as configured by the actor system.
Return to instruct the downing shell how to react.

and
which provides simple access to the
Abstracts over different Encoder/Decoder and other serialization mechanisms.
Container of tags a concrete actor identity was tagged with.
Representation of the distributed invocation in the Behavior APIs.
This needs to be removed eventually as we remove behaviors.
Allows for configuring of remote calls by setting task-local values around a remote call being made.

is a confined space which runs and manages Actors.
Uniquely identifies a DistributedActor within the cluster.
Internal context object used by the actor system to support per-actor state, such as necessary to implement lifecycle watch etc.
Settings which allow customizing logging behavior by various sub-systems of the cluster system.
Actor messaging specialized serialization engine.

which can be used to perform actor serialization specific tasks
such as resolving an actor ref from its serialized form.

Configuring security aspects of your cluster system.

marks nodes that have been unreachable as
after a configurable timeout.
Discovering actors is an important aspect of distributed programming, as it is
primary way we can discover actors on other nodes,
and communicate with them.
Marks a type that can be “pretty” printed, meaning often multi-line well formatted/aligned.
manages a set of subscribers and forwards every event published to it to
all its subscribers. An actor can subscribe/unsubscribe to the event stream via
constructs. Subscribers will be watched and removed in case they terminate.
Special actor ref personality, which can handle
s.
Backoff strategy exponentially yielding greater time amounts each time when triggered.

Monitoring distributed actor lifecycles regardless of their location.
Represents the name and placement within the actor hierarchy of a given actor.
Dead letter errors may be transported back to remote callers, to indicate the recipient they tried to contact is no longer alive.
A “dead letter” is a message (“letter”) that is impossible to deliver to its designated recipient.
Clustering multiple actor system instances into a single Distributed Actor System.

Defines which per actor (group) metrics are enabled for a given actor.

strategies.

A peer-to-peer cluster actor system implementation for Swift.
Cluster-aware (atomic broadcast style, push/pull-gossip) Receptionist implementation.
Error indicating that after an operation some unused bytes are left.
Generic transportable Error type, can be used to wrap error types and represent them as best as possible for transporting.
Configure metrics exposed by the actor system.
A receptionist is a system actor that allows users to register actors under
a key to make them available to other parts of the system, without having to
share a reference with that specific part directly.
Namespace for
metadata.
Allows controlling the cluster, e.g. by issuing join/down commands, or subscribing to cluster events.
Describes a node which at some point was known to the leader and moved to
by whichever strategy it implements for this. Generally, up members are fully ready
members of the cluster and are most likely known to many if not all other nodes in the cluster.

is a node that is participating in a clustered system.

Cluster namespace.
Represents a single segment (actor name) of an ActorPath.
The cluster system offers a number of built-in observability capabilities about the state of the cluster, as well as distributed actors it manages.
Provides a distributed actor with the ability to “watch” other actors lifecycles.

is a conceptual distributed actor that is guaranteed to have at-most one
instance within the cluster system among all of its
members.

Serialization manifests are used to carry enough information along a serialized payload,
such that the payload may be safely deserialized into the right type on the recipient system.

Represents cluster events, most notably regarding membership and reachability of other members of the cluster.
A high-level introduction to distributed actor systems.
Leader election allows for determining a “leader” node among members.
